text: Don't worry, we all do this on our free time anyway! The code is already an app of InteractiveChaos.jl and thus I think you should be able to run it immediately with your nice 4D Hamiltonian (in fact it will probably look even cooler)

text: <@U8J1KET6K> how hard would it be to adapt the code, such that instead of a 3D Scatter a 3D mesh is cutted?

elements.text: how hard would it be to adapt the code, such that instead of a 3D Scatter a 3D mesh is cutted?

text: <@UUS6GL8BH> The code is composed into two parts: the first is to calculate the cut (called Poincare section). The second is to plot it. It is trivial to adapt the scatter plot to a line or whatever plot, as the scatter plot is done by a 1 loc calling `scatter`. It is *impossible* to change the Poincare section from a scatter plot to anything else, as by definition the Poincare section is a discrete dynamical system and there is no lines connecting the individual points.

elements.text: The code is composed into two parts: the first is to calculate the cut (called Poincare section). The second is to plot it. It is trivial to adapt the scatter plot to a line or whatever plot, as the scatter plot is done by a 1 loc calling
scatter

impossible
to change the Poincare section from a scatter plot to anything else, as by definition the Poincare section is a discrete dynamical system and there is no lines connecting the individual points.

text: I don't want to do anything with discrete dynamical systems, just wondering how much I could copy from the src code of this, because essentially I want at the left a `mesh` plot with a transparent plane and on the right hand side the cross section of it

text: I think you can copy almost all of the code, simply change the `lines!` plot to a mesh plot. Just transform the data you have into a `Dataset` (see dynamical systems documentation, pretty much a vector of SVector, each SVector being a vertex of the mesh)

text: ah no, sorry, you can't use the `poincaresos` function from DYnamicalSystems.jl (that calculates the section) because it assumes that the Dataset is time-ordered, i.e. each point follows after the next, like a trajectory.
